column6: you do the only natural thing. You take this angel
column7: chop him up into tiny pieces
column8: and dry him out. Then
column9: you make <kanji>tea</kanji> out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat
column10: though.

column1: - Hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*"	<reading><jp>ちゃ
column3: さ	"In your <kanji>tea</kanji> you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says ""To <reading>Cha</reading>d
column4: you'll make an awesome angel."" Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.

column1: - Hint: It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad
column3: because now you feel kind of bad."

column1: 38	璧	Disc

column6: 丶	"You offer a <radical>hot pepper</radical> to the <radical>king</radical>
column7: and he gives you a drop of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a disc. And not just any old disc at that. It's a jade disc.

column1: Have you ever seen ancient Chinese jade discs with holes in the middle? That's what this kanji is referring to.
- Hint: You took a long time to pick out the perfect hot pepper. Only the best for the king
column2: right? It burned your hands a little as you held it on your way to the palace. You were hoping for something pretty special in return
column3: but you never imagined it would be a drop that magically turns into a disc. Wow!"	<reading><jp>へき</jp></reading>	<jp>たま</jp>	None	へき	"Wait
column4: did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on?

column1: - Hint: You start to realize just how crazy the situation is. Seriously. How the heck is a drop able to turn into a jade disc?"

column2: but only if they made it absolutely perfect.

column1: - Hint: Imagine trying to kiss someone with a piece of thread between your lips. Feel the thread getting all entangled between the two of you as you lock lips. It’s really detracting from the experience." らく から None らく "This is your first kiss ever so getting a thread to entangle between your lips was really bad luck (らく). The person you were trying to kiss got really grossed out by the thread and tried to push you away but was so entangled with the thread that they were unable. Bad luck indeed.
- Hint: Picture yourself being tied to someone by the tongue with thread. You can’t escape
column2: and you can’t believe your bad luck. Feel the thread tugging on your tongue as you try to get yourself untangled."

column5: す "To remember the sounds し and す we'll use these mnemonics:

column1: There is a <kanji>child</kanji> standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>) in a <reading>su</reading>it (<jp>す</jp>) in front of you. You yelp
column3: and it's back to being a child. Are... all children really just sheep in suits?!

column1: - Hint: The child runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep in a suit again
column2: but whenever you yell and point
column3: it turns back. You're the only one who can see this sheep suit child!!"

column3: you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny
column4: the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (<jp>すい</jp>). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you
column5: and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected
column6: and you come back to the surface

column8: it’s very
column9: very <reading>swee</reading>t. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet
column10: this water is).

column1: - Hint: I know that was a long one
column2: but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold
column3: smell
column4: etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with <jp>すい</jp> (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part
column5: the more vividly you imagined it
column6: the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi."

2	々	Repeater
column3: Reduplication
column4: Iteration Mark	Prison
column5: Drop	勹
column6: 丶	"This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact
column7: what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: <jp>人々</jp> is actually <jp>人人</jp>. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji
column8: because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it.

column1: To remember that this kanji is the repeater
column3: think of a <radical>drop</radical> of water dripping into a <radical>prison</radical>. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again
column4: driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.

column1: - Hint: Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function
column2: try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it."	None	<reading><jp>のま</jp></reading>	None	のま	"In Japanese
column3: this symbol is often called the <jp>のま</jp> because it looks like the katakana characters <jp>ノ</jp> and <jp>マ</jp> put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't
column4: think of it this way:

column1: Your mom is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling ""<reading>No ma</reading>!"" (<jp>のま</jp>) but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track
column3: repeating forever.

column1: - Hint: If you feel like you're so full you're about to burst
column2: and if you imagine your mom doing this to you (how could you
column3: ma?)
column4: you should be able to remember the reading of this kanji. That being said
column5: the reading is mostly only useful in the event that you have to identify a <jp>々</jp>—otherwise
column6: you won't see it much."
